With the increasing energy demands for electronic devices and electrical vehicles, anode materials for lithium-ion batteries with high specific capacity, good cyclic and rate performance become one of the focal areas of research. A class of them is the copper-based nanomaterials that have thermal and chemical stability, high theoretical specific capacity, low price and environment friendliness. Now this kind of nanomaterials has been recognized as one of the critical materials for lithium-ion batteries due to the predicted future market growth. Current status of different copper-based materials which produced already are discussed. In this review, comprehensive summaries and evaluations are given in synthesis strategies, tailored material properties and different electrochemical performance. Recent progress of general copper-based nanomaterials for lithium-ion batteries is carefully presented.
voltage, and low self-discharge rate. Applications of lithium-ion batteries are ranging from portable consumer electronics to aerospace and electric vehicles.[27–29] As compared with other batteries, lithium-ion battery still have some disadvantages, such as insufficient energy density and power density, safety issues, depending on the quality of the electrode and electrolyte materials.[30,31] So far, many efforts have been done to improve the performances of lithium-ion battery. The energy density problem can be overcomed by developing novel electrode materials like lithium metal or silicon-(active metal) alloys which represent better hope for quite great enhancement in capacity.[32–34] Usually, the electrode material can pro-
vide pathways for shuttling lithium ions, benefitting both fast ion transport and charge balance.[35] Electrode materials are the determining factor for the battery performances. In many applications, electrode materials require not only high electrical conductivity and thermal conductivity, but also sufficiently high strength, hardness, heat resistance and wear resistance.[36–39] In previous research, carbonaceous materials have played key roles in anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Yet there still existed the unsolvable safety problem about lithium dendrite growth on the surface of carbon anodes.[40] As a result, developing new anode materials with improved cycling performance, high working potential and outstanding thermal stability to substitute conventional carbonaceous materials has become a top priority.
New materials with higher energy density, better safety, and faster charge/discharge speed are critical to achieve better performances.[41,42] Nanomaterials which differs from their bulk nature have been extensively studied (such as the transition metal oxide nanostructures of Fe2O3, Co3O4, NiO and ZnO, etc.).[13,43–48] These types of materials have many advantages and great potential in terms of energy storage and conversion applications.[49–54] How to control their synthesis, surface morphology and use of their advantages in terms of energy storage and conversion becomes particularly important.[55–63] Conventional battery materials may not completely meet the requirement of the rapid development of modern society.[64,65]
In metal matrix composites, there is a striking copperbased composite material. Copper is the most widely used metallic materials according to the history.[9,66] Based on charge storage mechanism, copper-based nanomaterials are well known as a typical electrode material.[67–72] With the effort of a large number of predecessors, now we can add transition

Copper-Based Nanomaterials for High-Performance Lithium-Ion Batteries
Jing Xu, Peng Gu, Jian Zhang, Huaiguo Xue, and Huan Pang*

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Modern economy largely depends on the basis of fossil energy. However, the resources that support half of the economy is approaching depletion rapidly in the 21st Century.[1–10] As a result of energy shortage, electrochemical energy storage technologies including batteries, fuel cells and electrochemical capacitors have begun to emerge.[11–13] Among those energyconversion devices, oxygen reduction plays a key role in which an oxygen molecule receives electrons to form a product.[14,15] High-quality, low-cost batteries will play a vital role in future society.[16–19] Batteries not only provide power to mobile device,[20,21] but also could store energy from non-continuous sources like wind. As the same time, various electric vehicles relied on battery technology are important for reducing pollution. Among different batteries, lithium batteries have been widely used due to the obvious benefits of small size, light weight, long lifetime and no memory effect.[22–26]
Lithium-ion battery technology was first commercialized in 1991, and has become one of the most successful energy storage devices due to its high energy density, high operating

ie w metal like copper to composite materials, which shows excel-lent physical and chemical properties.[63,73–79] For example,
compared with titanium-based compounds which have been positive researched as typically anode materials, copper-based materials show their superiorities in lithium-ion batteries. In Chen’s group, they synthesized the Cu-doped Li4Ti5O12-TiO2 nanosheets.[3] The previous data displayed that Li4Ti5O12 had a low electronic conductivity (merely 10−13 Scm−1), especially in high rate currents. Moreover, its relatively low theoretical capacity is only 175 mA h g−1. But with the addition of copper, the discharge capacity of the 0.05 Cu-doped sample can up to 190 mA h g−1 at 1C, and even 144 mA h g−1 was obtained at 30 C after 100 cycles. Moreover, after 500 cycles at 30C, the discharge capacity remained at approximately 130 mA h g−1. The excellent electrochemical performance confirmed the advantages of copper-based materials. There is another example that in reference,[33] Qu et al. studied self-aligned Cu–Si core–shell nanowire array. They have found that although silicon nanowires (NWs) act as a promising anode, the high aspect ratio and small contact areas with the current collector of the NWs could cause high electrical resistance and other technical issues. In their study, they added copper core functions as a built-in current collector which provide very short (nm) electron transport pathways as well as backbone to improve mechanical strength. And the initial electrochemical tests showed a good performance. More similar cases will be introduced in the following sections. Due to these advantages, many scientists local and international have shown great interest in copper-based composites in the application of lithium batteries.[80–90]
In this review, we focus on the copper based nanocomposite in lithium-ion battery applications. Some categories are introduced: alloys, copper(II/I) oxide and other element nanomaterials. As every tiny factor can affect the morphology, property and so on, we present and discuss the synthesis strategies, tailored material properties and different electrochemical performances in the following sections.

sections.heading: 2. Cu Alloys and Related Composites
sections.text: As a metallic material, alloy which characteristics of two or more metal may have superior electrochemical properties than that of Cu alone. The conductivity, thermal conductivity and strength of copper alloys is often an inverse relationship. Depending on the number of constituent elements, alloy can be divided into binary alloys, ternary alloys and multicomponent alloys.[91–94] This review, mainly refers to alloys such as binary alloy, multi-component alloy, alloy composites with carbon source and so on. Meanwhile, in the following introduction, divides it into three parts: copper directed as current collector, copper alloy directed as anode, and copper plays dual roles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Copper Directed as Current Collector
sections.text:
Lahiri et al. presented a novel binder-free multiwall carbon nanotube(MWCNT) structure which through a two-step process of catalyst deposition and chemical vapor deposition(CVD) and directly grown on a copper current collector as an anode in Li ion batteries.[95] The high specific capacity of interfacecontrolled MWCNT structure is almost three times as that of graphite. Meanwhile, at a charging/discharging rate of 3 C up to 50 cycles, there is no capacity degradation. Electrochemical characteristics of the MWCNT-on-Cu electrode are presented in Figure 1. Figure 1a shows that at first two charge–discharge cycles of the MWNT-on-Cu anode, the first discharge cycle (lithiation) exhibited a very high capacity of 2547 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C rate. While the following delithiation cycle showed a specific capacity of 1455 mA h g−1. Even at the 3 C rate, a reversible capacity of 767 mA h g−1 was observed, which is almost twice the theoretical capacity of graphite. Figure 1b demonstrates the Coulombic efficiency of the MWNT-on-Cu anode. We can see

Nam et al. electroplated Sn on a porous Cu foam substrate which consists of grape-like Cu nanodeposits to fabricate 3D Sn electrode.[96] During the process, small amounts of Cu6Sn5 formed at the interface of Sn deposits and the Cu foam which made up the Sn-Cu6Sn5/Cu foam electrode. This formed electrode exhibits better electrochemical properties than the Sn electrode electrodeposited on a smooth Cu foil such as cyclic performance and charge capacity. Figure 2 exhibits the cycle performance of the Sn electrode deposited onto a smooth Cu foil compared with that of the Sn/Cu foam electrode. According to the picture, we can see that after 20 cycles, the Sn/Cu foam electrode reserves a charge capacity of 686.1 mA h g−1 and after 50 cycles, it remains 476.4 mA h g−1. Those are corresponding to 83.5% and 58.0% of its initial charge capacity of 821.5 mA h g−1 and 655.5 mA h g−1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Copper Alloy Directed as Anode
sections.text:
As an important candidate for electrode materials of lithium-ion batteries, graphene/metal composites have huge active surface areas to accelerate the electron transfer between electrode and detection molecules. In Guo’s group, they fabricated the copper
nanoparticles (Cu NPs) spaced reduced graphene oxide (rGO) films and they used the method of integrating electrophoresis deposition (EPD) with thermal H2 annealing to controlling the mean diameter of the Cu NPs by tuning the annealing temperature.[97] When being as lithium-ion battery (LIB) electrodes (vs Li/Li+) that devoted into the electrochemical performance tests, the products showed their superior advantages. This novel LIB has a high charge/discharge capacity (>463 mA h g−1), an excellent reversibility, and a high Coulombic efficiency (nearly 100%) for 300 cycles at a current density of 0.2 A g−1. It also exhibits good rate capacity: 849 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1, 618 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1, 516 mA h g−1 at 0.3 A g−1, and 470 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1. These excellent representations may give the credit to the adding of the implantation of Cu NPs and the self-merits of graphene.
Chen et al. synthesized mesoporous Sn-Cu composite by using Cu6Sn5, Cu3Sn, Sn and silica SBA-15 which is as the hard template.[98] Figure 3a is the schematic illustration of the manufacturing operation and Figure 3b and c are scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron micrscopy (TEM) images of mesoporous Sn-Cu composite. This as-prepared composite with a large pore volume of 0.517 cm3 g−1 a large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 197.8 m2 g−1 can be used for the anode material of lithium-ion batteries. The comparison of mesoporous and bulk Sn-Cu can be observed in Figure 3d and e. At the

1st cycle, mesoporous Sn-Cu delivered a lower discharge capacity of 530.4 mA h g−1 than that of bulk Sn-Cu while following the capacity of bulk Sn-Cu dropped very rapidly under 500 mA g−1. The mesoporous Sn-Cu’s capacity slowly dropped to 174.5 mA h g−1 at 200th cycle but the capacity of bulk Sn-Cu is much lower than that of mesoporous Sn-Cu.
Due to the non-toxicity, stable thermal and mechanical structure, abundance and electrical conductivity, graphite becomes the most commonly used anode material in commercial LIBs.[11,99–106] Further experiment about Graphene/Cu6Sn5 nanocomposite was done by Chen et al. They successfully prepared the Graphene/Cu6Sn5 nanocomposite through a facile one-pot method.[107] Cu6Sn5 nanoparticles which the average size is below 10 nm are encapsulated into graphene nanosheets. The advantages of graphene are enhancing mechanical properties, preventing the aggregation between Cu6Sn5 nanoparticles as well as providing enough void space to buffer volume change of Cu6Sn5. Due to the intriguing structure, the products deliver excellent high rate performance and great long term cycling stability. Observe from the electrical testing results, we see that at a high current density of 500 mA g−1, the capacity can obtain up to 411.4 mA h g−1 after 1600 cycles. Meanwhile the reversible capacity is as large as 220 mA h g−1 at 10 000 mA g−1 (merely 80 s for discharge or charge). A core-shell-structure carbon-coated nanoscale Cu6Sn5 is prepared by Cui et al. They used an in situ polymerization method as well as a surface modification technology.[108] Illustration of the preparation process for the core-shell carbon coated nanosized Cu6Sn5 is shown in Figure 4a. The composite combines with an excellent cycling stability thanks to the merits of intermetallic compounds and nano-sized anode materials. For comparison, the electrochemical performance of nanoscale Cu6Sn5 and the Cu6Sn5-carbon composite were tested in a combination with a metallic lithium negative electrode under identical conditions by cycling the cells between 0 V and 2.0 V at a constant current density of 100 mA h g−1. The Figure 4b shows us that the charge/discharge curves of the nanoscale Cu6Sn5. It exhibits a reversible capacity of 436 mA h g−1 and a sloping discharge/ charge behavior with a discharge capacity of 791 mA h g−1 in the first discharge/charge cycle, consistenting with a Coulombic efficiency of 55% (as shown in Figure 4d). The nano-sized Cu6Sn5 exhibits a poor cycling performance with a capacity of merely 156 mA h g−1 and a 64% loss of the first charge capacity after 50 cycles. The core-shell carbon-coated Cu6Sn5 exhibits an excellent electrochemical performance. As shown in Figure 4c, it delivers a discharge capacity of 802 mA h g−1 and a reversible capacity of 437 mA h g−1 in the first discharge/charge cycle, corresponding to a Coulombic efficiency of 55%, shown in

Kepler et al. have discovered new intermetallic insertion electrodes (anodes)-LixCu6Sn5 (x ≈ 13) for rechargeable lithium batteries that with a two-phase reaction. They inserted lithium into the intermetallic compound Cu6Sn5.[109] Subsequent test cases showed that when x = 13, the theoretical capacity of LixCu6Sn5 with a NiAs-type structure can up to 358 mA h g−1. This result corresponds to a fully lithiated composition Li2.17CuSn0.83 and is close to the theoretical capacity of lithiated graphite LiC6 (372 mA h g−1).
Ren et al. synthesized the amorphous structure nanometer copper-tin alloy anode materials via a reverse microemulsion technique.[110] Thanks to its particle size that controlled by
appropriate surfactant content, the alloy demonstrates excellent electrochemical performances. The electrochemical performance data showed that with particle size of 50–60 nm, the nanometer copper-tin material presented the best performance. The result shows us the cycle performance curves of copper-tin material synthesized by microemulsion method. From the picture we can see that over the full voltage range 0.0–1.2 V, except for the first cycle, the following 60 cycles of the specific capacity (300 mA h g−1) and columbic efficiency are stable. And in the 50th cycle, the stable specific capacity can remain 93.3%. At the same time, the electrode also keeps a high Coulomb efficiency of 98–99% in the following cycles.
Zhao et al. presented Ge-Cu nanoparticles (Ge-Cu NPs) which can consist an anode material were fabricated through a one-step inert gas condensation method.[111] Amorphous Ge and orthorhombic Cu3Ge phase synthesized the Ge-Cu NPs

which have good performances during the lithiation/delithiation process. At 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, the reversible discharge capacities can determine of 843, 773, 680, 516 mA h g−1, respectively, with a Coulombic efficiency higher than 96%.
A germanium/copper germanide/carbon (Ge/Cu3Ge/C) composite is prepared by Chae et al. via the Pechini method.[112] The reaction raw materials such as GeO2, CuSO4, and citric acid/ethylene glycol are the Ge, Cu and carbon sources. The microstructure and electrochemical properties of this nanocomposite are compared to those of germanium/carbon (Ge/C) that is prepared without the copper precursor. In the latter composite, irregular-shaped submicrometer-sized (0.4–0.5 μm) Ge particles are dispersed inside a carbon matrix. Figure 5 compares the cycle performance for two electrodes. It shows that two electrodes exhibit a slight amount of irreversible capacity in every cycle. For example, at the 20th the Coulombic efficiency cycle is 94% for the Ge/C-Li and 97% for Ge/Cu3Ge/C-Li cells, respectively.
Single-crystalline copper germinate (CuGeO3) nanowires combined with reduced graphene oxide (RGO) were produced by Chen et al. through a one-pot hydrothermal route.[113] Large Li storage capacity and a stable cyclability of CuGeO3 may thank to the in situ formed CuO and Ge nanocrystals after the initial discharge process of CuGeO3. From the Figure 6, we can more directly observe the excellent performances of CuGeO3@RGO composite. Compared with CuGeO3 nanowires, the CuGeO3@ RGO composite exhibits high lithium storage capacity and
remarkable cycling stability. Figure 6a shows that when initial discharge and charge specific capacities are 2544 and 1157 mA h g−1 respectively, indicating a Coulombic efficiency of 45.5%. After the first few cycles, the germanium in the electrode can lead to approximately 100% Coulombic efficiency and after 10 cycles, the capacity retained was above 1000 mA h g−1 as well as 780 mA h g−1 after 130 cycles. As illustrated in Figure 6b, CuGeO3 nanowires alone exhibit stable and reversible capacities of 900, 800, 740, 700 and 680 mA h g−1 when the current densities increase from 100, 200, 400, 800 to 1000 mA g−1, at the same time, the CuGeO3@RGO composite exhibited better rate capability of 1428, 1242, 1092, 958 and 879 mA h g−1 respectively. Above performances may thank to the Cu nanoparticles which ensure good electron transport in the nanowires as well as RGO that provides an electronic conductive network for the Li storage kinetics between the nanowires.
Wu et al. added Cu2+ as a favorable dopant in synthesized Li[NiCoMn]1/3O2 from the recovery of spent Li-ion batteries by wet chemical processes and they investigated the effect of Cudoping on the electrochemical behaviors.[114] During their process, Li[NiCo1−xCuxMn]1/3O2 (x = 0, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06 and 0.08) were synthesized and their electrochemical performance tests were carried out individually. As an increase of x, the initial discharge capacity of Li[NiCo1−xCuxMn]1/3O2 gradually dropped. On the contrary, the rate property and capacity retention were remarkably enhanced. The results suggest that Cu can be used as a beneficial dopant to partially substitute Co in synthesizing Li[NiCoMn]1/3O2 using in LIBs.

sections.heading: 2.3. Copper Plays Dual Roles
sections.text:
Nanoporous copper (NPC) synthesized by Zhang et al. is applied as both the current collector and substrate of active material in the lithium-ion battery.[115] They used dealloying technology to make the nanoporous copper has three-dimensional structure composed of large channels (hundreds of nanometers) and small pores (tens of nanometers) on the channel walls which we can catch from Figure 7. Anodes were prepared to compare with each other, one is a thin layer of tin on NPC and copper foil (Sn@NPC), the other is a tin-coated planar copper foil (Sn@CF). By comparing the two above electrodes, we can see from the Figure 8 that the Sn@NPC

demonstrates better electrochemical properties. For example, in the first cycle, its charge capacity is 1.68 mA h cm−2 and that is 20 times higher than that of Sn@CF. At the same time, after 10 cycles and 20 cycles, the reversible capacity retention can remain 58.5% and 45.2% which is much higher than 34.8% and 24.3% of Sn@CF. Other than the first several cycles, the Coulombic efficiency of Sn@NPC maintains above 95%, and that is still better than 80% of Sn@CF electrodes.
Anodes (modified carbons are widely adopted) generally have higher capacities than common cathodes.[99] The team also has successfully synthesized core-shell Cu@Cu6Sn5 nanowires.[98] They used anodized Cu(OH)2 nanorods as the substrate and an electrodeposition process to heel by the 3D technology.[116] Figure 9 is the schematic illustration of the fabrication process. Then the prepared Sn-Cu composites were heat-treated at different temperatures. They prepared four samples at different heat-treated temperatures: room temperature (denoted as SnCu-RT), 80 °C (Sn-Cu-80), and 200 °C (Sn-Cu-200), Cu(OH)2 particles obtained by anodizaion in 3 M NaOH aqueous solution were used as the substrate to produce Sn-Cu composite (denoted as Sn-Cu-P). We can get clearly from the Figure 9 that up to 200 cycles at 1 C, the Sn-Cu-80 demonstrates the best cycling performance of the four samples. As for Sn-Cu-200, its discharge capacity dropped rapidly and the capacity retention is merely 17.6%. Nearly as Sn-Cu-P, it also dropped down and is merely 0.003 mA h cm−2. When heat-treated at 80 °C, the Cu6Sn5 exhibits the greatest electrochemical performances.

sections.heading: 3.1. CuO(II) and Its related Composites
sections.text:
Metal oxides with high power density and high energy density have been widely recognized as the next-generation anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. A variety of metal oxides have been explored as alternatives to the commercial carbonaceous anodes.[117] Transition-metal oxides have devoted to be promising high-performance materials for the next generation

of LIBs.[118] Transition-metal oxides such as CuO is well-known as potential alternative anode materials of next-generation lithium-ion batteries.[119–122] Thanks to their much higher lithium storage capacities, low cost, and eco-friendliness, they have been caused great attention.
Bai et al. prepared leaf-like mesoporous CuO by treating commercial Cu(OH)2 powder in the room temperature at a befitting time.[123] The amount of Cu(OH)2 was placed at room temperature in air. Six months later, the decomposition of Cu(OH)2 made the blue powders changed into black. Then, the black powders were what they wanted. And they used field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), and high resolution TEM (HRTEM) techniques to examine the structural features and morphology of the obtained leaf-like mesoporous CuO which are shown in Figure 10. The resulting mesoporous leaf-like CuO exhibited superior electrical performances, including high reversible capacity (694.7 mA h g−1 at 500 mA h g−1), stable capacity retention (99.3% in 300 cycles), and high rate capability (495 mA h g−1 at 2000 mA h g−1). The mesoporous leaf-like CuO is going to be an outstanding anode material for the lithium-ion batteries because of their extremely cycling property and good rate performance guarantee.
Further research is done by Wang et al. who prepared three different morphology controlled copper oxide materials including porous microspheres, flower-like, and thorn-like CuO via environmental-friendliness and facile methods.[124] The CuO microspheres were prepared by ordinary solution chemistry, while other two structures were prepared hydrothermally. Due to the selection of sulfate counter ions or chloride in the precursor salts, following were the structural transformations arising. Figure 11a to c show the SEM images of the three samples. According to the electrochemical properties which were examined latter (Figure 11d), they found that CuO
microspheres had an excellent reversible cycle capacity from 664.1 to 429.0 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles, which is as well as good rate performance and Coulombic efficiency between asprepared CuO electrodes.
A new novel 1D highly porous CuO nanorods were produced via a friendly but very simple approach in large-quantities in the work of Wang et al. (Figure 12).[125] What is interesting is that they controlled the pore size by adjusting the sintering temperature during the calcination process. With the rising of calcination temperature, they got different pore size of CuO from the range of ∼0.4 nm to 22 nm. Three samples are got under different temperatures that sample A is without heat-treated, sample B is heat-treated in a muffle furnace at 200 °C for 6 h and sample C is 400 °C for 6 h. Figure 12a and b show the comparison of the three samples. As a result, they found the product whose porous size in the range of ∼6 nm to 22 nm (sample C) had excellent electrochemical performances, better than most reported CuO nanocomposites. The CuO material exhibits an excellent reversible capacity of 654 mA h g−1 and 93% capacity retention at a rate of 0.5 C over 200 cycles. Even at 6 C it still delivers wonderful high rate capacity of 410 mA h g−1.
Porous CuO hollow architectures manufactured by Wu et al. with wonderful octahedral morphology exhibit greatly enhanced performances as the anode materials of lithium storage, such as the excellent cycling stability and good rate capability.[126] The porous CuO hollow octahedra is manufactured easily by annealing Cu-based metal-organic framework (MOF) templates and thermal transformation process is in the next moment.
Xiang et al. synthesized the nanostructured copper oxide spheres via the stirred solution of cupric acetate and ammonium hydroxide.[127] They used the hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as a surfactant in order to modify the surface morphology of CuO spheres. With the existing of

CTAB, nano-needle arrays can be ordered arrangement on the surface of the CuO spheres. Figure 13a–d shows the morphologies of the formation of CuO with and without CTAB. A single CuO sphere with 2 μm is composited of many nanoneedles with the width of 20–40 nm and more than the length of 300 nm. The hierarchical structure which likes needle has a greatly increasing in the contact site between CuO and electrolyte. According to this, the hierarchical structure can provide more areas for Li+ accommodation, make the diffusion length of Li+ short and strengthen the reactivity of electrode reaction. The electrochemical performance test that demonstrated in Figure 13e indicated that the reversible capacity of the prepared CuO can respectively reserve 62.4% and 56.4% of the 2nd cycle at 0.1 C and 1 C after 50 cycles. This figure shows the comparison of cycling performance of the CuO electrodes at different rates (from the 2nd cycle to the 50th cycle) and we can obverse clearly that CuO spheres with CTAB have better properties than that absence of CTAB.
Chen et al. developed a handy and inexpensive to fabricate the CuO mesoporous nanosheet cluster array electrodes.[128] CuO mesoporous nanosheet cluster arrays (MNCAs) directly grown on a Cu substrate by an ammonia vapor-phase corrosion route. Lacking of binders and conductivity agents, the CuO MNCAs as integrated anodes for lithium-ion batteries
demonstrated a higher reversible capacity of 639.8 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at a rate of 1 C and a high-rate capability of 548.8 mA h g−1 at a rate of 10 C.
So far, we have talked about CuO material only, in the following part, we introduce some examples about compound of CuO and carbon source. Impressively, the introduction of carbon-based matrix or carbon coating on the metal oxides could significantly enhance electro-chemical performance for LIBs, especially at high-rate capability. It is believed that the carbon component can not only improve the electrical conductivity of the electrode, but also ameliorate the aggregation and pulverization of electrochemical active materials, resulting in the enhancement of cycling life.[129,130]
Cao et al. combined electro-deposition of CuO and atomiclayer-deposition-assisted formation of carbon nanoflakes shell to prepare the novel CuO/C core/shell nanowire arrays.[131] In their case the CuO nanowire arrays were synthesized by the ED method. Then, they could get the desired result via electrochemical layer assembly and the ALD technique. The morphology and size distribution of the CuO/C core/ shell nanowire arrays are shown in Figure 14a and b. Compared with the unmodified CuO nanowire arrays and the CuO/C core/shell nanowire arrays (shown in Figure 14c–f) we can easily find that the latter has better electrical properties.
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150
Figure 12. (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation process of the porous CuO nanorod compounds. (b) Cycle performance (start from the 2nd cycle), and (c) rate performance of the three CuO samples (starting from the 2nd cycle). All panels reproduced with permission.[125] Copyright 2012, Royal Society of Chemistry.
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim 11wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew
Obviously, the CuO/C core/shell nanowire arrays show higher current densities and smaller peak potential separations than the unmodified CuO nanowire counterpart, manifesting their superior electrochemical properties. There more, the initial Coulombic efficiency of the unmodified CuO nanowire arrays is about 65.9%, lower than that of the CuO/C core/shell nanowire arrays (72.7%).
An optimized nanostructure design for electrode materials for high-performance lithium-ion batteries was realized by introducing three-dimensional (3D) graphene networks into transition metal oxide nanomicrostructures. Self-assembled CuO and CuO/graphene urchin-like structures have been successfully synthesized by Wang et al. via a simple solution method.[132] When being used as anode materials in lithiumion batteries, compared with pure CuO urchin-like structure, the CuO/graphene nanocomposite demonstrated an ascendant enhanced rate performance and cycling performance. As is shown in the testing results, under a current density of 65 mA g−1, the CuO/graphene electrode can stably deliver a reversible capacity of 600 mA h g−1 during all the 100 dischargecharge cycles. Even at a high current density of 6400 mA g−1, the specific charge capacity of the CuO/graphene nanocomposite is still as high as 150 mA h g−1, which is three times larger than that of graphene (48 mA h g−1), while that of CuO is nearly null under the same current density. Above electrochemical performances could thanks to the 3D electrically conductive networks
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150

© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim12 wileyonlinelibrary.com

of graphene as well as the unique nanomicrostructure of the CuO/grapheme nanocomposite.
Analogously Zhou et al. have used a facile microwave-assisted method to synthesize CuO nanoleaves on graphene sheets (CuO/GNS) composite in which way Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, NaOH, ammonia and ethanol are served as raw materials and solvent. With the development of the experiment, the leaf-shaped rhombic pristine CuO were uniformly dispersed on GNS. When tested the electrochemical performances of the CuO/ GNS composites that as an anode material for Li-ion battery, the results showed satisfactory cyclic durability, high lithium storage capacity and rate capacity than pristine CuO. After 50 cycles at 100 mA g−1, the reversible capacity of the CuO/GNS composites can retained 600 mA h g−1. Meanwhile, even when cycled at various rates for 50 cycles, the capacity could recover to 600 mA h g−1 at the same current.[133] The influence of the synergy effect of the uniformly distributed CuO nanoleaves and graphene sheets is the result of the exceptional electrical properties. The overall electrode is highly conductive and structurally stable. Different from the above-mentioned graphene examples, this section we introduce carbon-coated CuO hollow spheres composited by Xu et al. During the process, they used a onestep, fast, scalable, and low-cost aerosol spray pyrolysis method to hit the mark that make a thin layer of CuO nanoparticles anchored to the outer carbon layer. The hollow spherical particles provide a capacity of 670 mA g−1 at 1 C and maintain the capacity for 300 cycles and 400 mA h g−1 at 50 C. Since the September of 2013, this is the best performance for CuO anodes reported to date and the exceptional electrochemical performance is resulted from the unique architecture of the carboncoated hollow structure.[134]

sections.heading: 3.2. Cu2O(I) and Its Related Composites
sections.text:
Cu2O, as a typical p-type semiconductor, has its own ubiquity in sensors, solar cells, electrode materials and catalysts. According to Ni et al., they used an electrochemical corrosion method to make Cu2O directly grow on Cu foam with
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150
Figure 14. (a,b) SEM-TEM images of CuO/C core/shell nanowire arrays. (c) CVs at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 between 0.01 and 3.0 V. (d) Charge/discharge profiles at the first two cycles. (e) Rate capability at different current densities ranging from 0.5 C to 4 C. (f) Cycling performance at 0.5 C and 3 C. All panels reproduced with permission.[131] Copyright 2015, Elsevier.
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim 13wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew the aid of H2O2.[135] In the testing of galvanostatic batteriesthe Cu2O-Cu electrode shows wonderful electrochemical properties such as excellent rate capability and cycle stability. As shown in Figure 15, it makes the charge/discharge capacity about 0.76 mA h cm−2 over 100 cycles without attenuation under a charge/discharge rate of 0.15 C come true. While testing more than 60 cycles at different rates from 0.2 to 35 C, the reversible capacity can hold 98.9% as the 5th-cycle discharge while lowering the charge/discharge rate to 0.2 C. The electrochemical properties are thanks to not only the excellent electric contacting of Cu2O and Cu foam but also a porous structure of the Cu2O electrode. According to above, the Cu2O-Cu electrode can be used in li-ion battery.
Xiang et al. synthesized highly ordered porous Cu2O film by using a self-assembled polystyrene sphere template to electrodeposite on copper foil.[136] We can see from the SEM images (Figure 16) that the spherical voids are well-ordered and close-packed in the film. The finished product reveals improved electrochemical cycling stabilities than the octahedral Cu2O powder and the dense Cu2O one. Thanks to the short diffusion length of Li+ and the adequate contact surface of Cu2O/electrolyte, capacity of the ordered porous film can respectively maintain 336 mA h g−1 and 213 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles at the rate of 0.1 C and 5 C. After 50 cycles, the reversible capacity of the prepared ordered porous Cu2O film can sustain 63.4%. What’s more, the direct contact between Cu2O and current collector also contributes to the enhanced high rate property.
By using the 3D technology, Liu et al. also applied the Three-dimensional (3D) nanoporous architectures which can develop a promising material for high-performance
lithium-ion batteries in the future.[137] Figure 17 shows the fabrication procedure for 3D NPCu@Cu2O anodes. For Li-ion, it can afford rapidly electron transport and fast and efficient pathways meanwhile in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), it can shorten the solid-state diffusion lengths. In their work, they successfully used low-cost selective etching of an electronbeam melted Cu50Al50 alloy and subsequent in situ thermal oxidation to synthesize 3D nanoporous copper-supported cuprous oxide. In the latter electrochemical performance test, the sample was employed as an anode in lithium-ion batteries. The sample showed a great lithium storage capacity of about 2.35 mA h cm−2 in the first cycle and retained 1.45 mA h cm−2 after 120 cycles.
Similar to above examples, 3D architecture was also successfully used by Xu et al. to fabricate the Cu2O@rGO (cuprous oxide sub-microspheres@reduced graphene oxide) nanosheets core-shell composites at room temperature.[138] The raw material are graphene oxide nanosheets and irregular cupric citrate. They were made by a one-step method through co-reduction. In the latter electrochemical tests, the Cu2O@rGO electrodes exhibit noticeable rate capability, cyclic stability and improved capacity than the bare Cu2O sub-microspheres and the simple physical mixture of Cu2O and rGO (Cu2O-rGO-M). After 50 cycles, the reversible capacity of the prepared Cu2O@rGO electrodes can deliver a discharge capacity of 534 mA h g−1 and sustain 94% of the initial capacity respectively at a low current density of 100 mA h g−1. While under a higher current density of 1000 mA h g−1, the Cu2O@rGO electrodes demonstrate a discharge capacity of 181 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles, which is about 4 times greater than that of the
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim14 wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev
ie w
bare Cu2O sub-microsphere electrodes. Besides this, at 1000 mA h g−1 relative to 100 mA h g−1, the rate capacity retention of Cu2O@rGO electrode is 74% and 38%, much greater than that 52% and 34% of Cu2O-rGO-M and 13% and 3% of bare Cu2O electrodes. Maybe giving the credit to the rGO coating and 3D architecture, the Cu2O@rGO has enhanced electrochemical performances.
Next, we will talk about Cu2O nanobeads over hydrogen exfoliated graphene (Cu2O NBs-HEG) that manufactured in the optimized Ar + H2 atmosphere by Ananya’s group.[139] In their case, they produced this new material via a controlled twostep synthesis technique. Different from other examples, the Cu2O beads are acting as a spacer in between the two dimensional planes and the tested specific capacity is almost thrice of the theoretical capacity of Cu2O. We can observe from the test results that the initial discharge capacity of the battery got enhanced to 2050 mA h g−1 and this is owing to the synergetic effect of copper oxide and wrinkled graphene.
Based on previous researches, micro- and nanocrystals can show different electrochemical activities with different facets. Chen et al. successfully synthesized the hollow octahedra of Cu2O via a facile reaction with copper acetate and N2H4 in the room-temperature.[140] Within <2 s, the easy reactions can be finished from Cu2+ to Cu (OH)42− and finally to Cu2O. Besides that, N2H4 can reduce the reaction and serve as an alkali. In the reaction, the acetate ions served as buffer and acted as counter ions, and they adjusted to the Cu2O particle surface. The chemical reactions which occurred can be represented as follows:

Cu 4OH Cu OH2 4 2( )+ →+ − − (2)
4Cu OH N H 2Cu O N 7H O+7OH 4

The hollow-octahedron@nanoparticles-aggregate core@shell structures were crank out by the introduction of NH4+ cations. Figure 18a–d show the FESEM and TEM of the Cu2O hollow octahedra and the Cu2O core@shell structures. The capacity is higher and the cycling stability of the core@shell structures is better than the hollow octahedra as lithium-ion battery anodes (Figure 18e). It turned out that the core@shell structures can endure larger volume changes than the hollow octahedra ones during electrochemical reactions. Meanwhile, the nanoparticles with subsize can diminish the diffusion path of the Li+ ions and electrons. For supercapacitors, the specific capacitance of the hollow octahedral ones is not as high as the core@shell structures.
CuO-Cu2O/graphene composite has been successfully prepared by Zhou et al., they carried on the combination of a microwave-assisted process and subsequent annealing. The morphology of the product showed that the hollow copper oxide nanospheres (composed of numerous CuO and Cu2O nanocrystals with a size of 120–200 nm) are uniformly anchored on graphene nanosheets.[141] As anode for Li-ion battery, the CuOCu2O/grapheme composite shows a highly reversible capacity and excellent rate performance. The enhanced electrochemical
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150

performances are attributed the success to possible synergistic effects between CuO, Cu2O and grapheme. Herein, we give some examples, the reversible capacity of the composite retains 487 mA h g−1 after 60 cycles at 200 mA g−1. Even when cycled at various rate (200, 500, 1000, 2000, 5000 mA g−1) for 60 cycles, the capacity can recover to 520 mA h g−1 at the current of 200 mA g−1.
4. Nanomaterials Consisting of Other Elements
4.1. CuFexOy
In earlier reports, transition metal oxides electrodes have been successfully used as anode material in lithium-ion batteries. Transition metal compounds are emerging electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries because of their multiple oxidation states and different ions.[142]
In Luo et al.’s work, they successfully fabricated the copper ferrite (CuFe2O4) nanofibers via an association of electrospinning and calcination process.[143] When the product obtained at 800 °C, we can see only peaks of CuFe2O4 which indicating the pure compound from the X-ray diffractometry test chart in Figure 19a. The 66 nm of an average diameter observed from
SEM and TEM images show the good continuous fiber morphology of the as-spun CuFe2O4 nanofibers. (Figure 19b-d) As an anode material for lithium-ion batteries, the electrospun CuFe2O4 nanofibers exhibit spectacular electrochemical properties. After 50 cycles, the electrospun CuFe2O4 nanofibers anode demonstrated a great initial discharge capacity from 1226.0 mA h g−1 at first to a stable capacity of 572.4 mA h g−1. At the same time, the electrodes also exhibit high capacities at greater discharge and charge rate. Owning to the high crystallinity, the fibrous structures as well as unique mesoporous, the electrospun CuFe2O4 nanofibers showed us a promising electrode material.
It happens that there is a similar case, Xing et al. also fabricated CuFe2O4 as anode material for high power lithium-ion anode batteries.[144] The reactants of the one-step solid state reaction are ferrous oxalate and copper acetate, following Cubic CuFe2O4 (c-CuFe2O4) and tetragonal CuFe2O4 (t-CuFe2O4) nanoparticles can be selectively prepared. According to the next survey, c-CuFe2O4 synthesized at 400 °C has smaller particle size but larger surface area than c-CuFe2O4 and t-CuFe2O4 synthesized at 800 °C. As a result, it showed excellent electrochemical performances such as better discharge capacities, superior cycling performance (950 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 60 cycles) as well as higher rate capability when it was used as an anode material of li-ion batteries. During the first discharge, the only difference is the insertion process of Li+ which owning to the influence of the two crystal phases. Meanwhile, the average particle size and the surface areas have influence in the storage capability and cycling ability. We can discover from the ex situ HRTEM analysis that the metastable FexCu1-x alloy existed during the discharged nanocomposition at the first time, and this showed us the interaction between metallic Cu particles and adjacent iron ions.
The next example has still do with CuFe2O4. At a low reaction temperature, Dong et al. have prepared nanoscale metallic Cu incorporated CuFe2O4 hexagonal platelets and graphene (Cu-CuFe2O4/G) composites via a one-pot and scalable hydrothermal strategy.[145] From the SEM images we can observe in the composites that the nanoscale metallic Cu is attached to CuFe2O4 hexagonal platelets and graphene sheets. We can observe from Figure 20 that as anode materials of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), thanks to its structural features, the composites exhibit excellent electrochemical performances. As the current rates gradually increased to 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1 C and 2 C, the corresponding obtained discharge capacities are 736 mA h g−1 for the 20th cycle, 653 mA h g−1 for the 30th cycle, 533 mA h g−1 for the 40th cycle, and 498 mA h g−1 for the 50th cycle. At a current density of 1000 mA g−1, the Cu-CuFe2O4/G composites show a wonderful capacity of 672 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles, besides good rate capability and cyclic stability. Above great performances should associate with the synergistic effect among CuFe2O4 hexagonal platelets, metallic Cu, and grapheme sheets.
Ma et al. prepared CuFe2O4-Fe2O3 porous nanosheets via an easy polyol-mediated route with calcination technology.[146] This hybrid material showed us that after 200 cycles, it can remain high specific capacity of 910 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C. Besides its good rate capability (417 mA h g−1 at 4 C) and superior capacity retention (0.02% capacity loss per cycle) also make it a hopeful
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim16 wileyonlinelibrary.com

anode material for li-ion batteries which should thanks to the highly porous structures of CuFe2O4-Fe2O3 porous nanosheets and good electrical and ion conductivity of the well-dispersed CuFe2O4 phase in the matrix.
4.2. CuCoxOy
Three dimensional (3D) macro-/mesoporous Co3O4 nanosheet arrays which synthesized by Fan et al. is produced by annealing β-Co(OH)2 nanosheet arrays electrodeposited on the 3D macroporous copper substrate with electroless plating.[147] Figure 21 presents to us that the morphologies of before and after electrodepositing on the 3D macroporous copper substrate. Being the anode of lithium-ion battery, the product displays wonderful electrochemical performance, for example, high reversible capacity (967 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 in the first cycle), excellent cyclability (after 500 cycles at 1 A g−1, the reversible capacity can remain 840 mA h g−1), and excellent high rate capacity (The reversible capacity at 20 A g−1 remains 38.0% of that of first cycle at 0.1 A g−1). Co3O4 nanosheets directly grown on 3D porous copper substrate can provide electron rapid

transport channels. Thanks to the macropores of 3D porous copper substrate, open space between Co3O4 nanosheets and mesopores of Co3O4 nanosheets which can provide lithium-ion rapid transport channels, the products exhibit excellent electrochemical performances.
It happens that there is a similar case, Xue et al. manufactured porous Co3O4 nanoneedle arrays growing on copper foils.[148] Being used as ultrafast charging/discharging of lithium-ion battery anodes, figures following show their electrochemical performances. Figure 22 shows the cycling performance of one battery under different high current surges continuously. As the current is 1.05 × 105 mA g−1, the voltage is charged from 0.001 to 3 V during 59 s (610 C, 610 half cycles per hour). Their discharge time (the voltage is discharged from 3 to

This implies that nanoarrays growing directly on copper foils are good candidates for anodes. Their reversible capacity at 0.5 C rate is 1167 mA h g−1.
Nam et al. synthesized directed Cu-doped h-CoO nanorods by thermal decomposition of Co(acac)3 and Cu(acac)2 in benzylamine which are very stable in an aqueous solution.[149] As an anode material for the lithium-ion batteries, the Cu-doped h-CoO nanorods shows wonderful electrochemical performances such as high initial Coulombic efficiency, ultrahigh capacity with excellent cycling performance and their suitability. As Cu-doping, compared to those of pure h-CoO nanorods which of 68.2% and h-CoO nanocrystal of 79.2%, the Coulombic efficiency of Cu-doped h-CoO nanorods improved
to 82.2%. After 50 cycles, the capacity curve can stay a stable capacity of 944 mA h g−1 for Cu-doped h-CoO nanorods which is higher than that of theoretical capacity (715 mA h g−1).
Highly symmetric Co3O4 hexapods prepared by Wang et al. with numerous porous nanorods which grown on copper foil are made via a facile hydrothermal method followed by thermal treatment.[150] We can observe its feature from Figure 23a. As binder-free anodes for lithium-ion batteries, the as-grown Co3O4 hexapods on copper foil showed us excellent electrochemical properties that after 40 cycles, the reversible capacity can remain high of 800 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and 440 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1. Above good electrochemical performance may result from the unique porous structure of the Co3O4 hexapods as well as the good contact with Cu foil. Furthermore, when coated with carbon (Figure 23b), the performance could
Figure 21. SEM images (a,b) of the as-electrodeposited 3D macroporous-Co(OH)2 nanosheet arrays. (c,d) of the macro-/mesoporous Co3O4 nanosheet arrays. All panels reproduced with permission.[147] Copyright 2014, Elsevier.
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim 19wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew
be further improved. As compared, we can see from the Figure 23c and d that after 40 cycles, the samples exhibit an enhanced reversible capacity of 1001 mA h g−1. Meanwhile after 50 cycles the reversible capacity cycling at 500 mA h g−1 is as high as 664 mA h g−1, much better than 392 mA h g−1 for the pure Co3O4 electrodes. These wonderful properties make the materials being promising anodes for lithium-ion batteries.

sections.heading: 4.3. Cu(NO3)2•x H2O
sections.text:
As for lithium-ion batteries new anode material, Cu(NO3)2•x H2O (x ≤ 2.5) is investigated for the first time by Wu et al. According to the electrochemical performance test, high initial discharge capacity of Cu(NO3)2•x H2O (x ≤ 2.5)/Li cell can reach to around 2200 mA h g−1.[151] To make a comparison, Cu(NO3)2•2.5 H2O were heat-treated at 80, 120 and 160 °C. Cu(NO3)2•x H2O (x < 2.5) which obtained at 160 °C exhibits the best reversible capacity of 597.6 mA h g−1 and the highest cycling stability after 30 cycles in the three samples. Above outstanding performances may result from the variation of crystal water, surface morphology, and particles size after heat-treatment at different temperatures. All the findings can provide the fact that Cu(NO3)2•x H2O (x ≤ 2.5) may be a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries.
Coincidentally, Jiang et al. synthesized an anode material for lithium-ion batteries copper nitrate hydrate Cu(NO3)2•2.5 H2O which shows superior high lithium storage capacity (2285 mA h g−1).[152] The test results showed that the lithium storage process of Cu(NO3)2•2.5H2O is in connection
with a quasi-reversible electrochemical conversion reaction. The Cu(NO3)2 can be generated by a conversion reaction in the reverse charge process. As a consequence, Cu(NO3)2•2.5 H2O shows the reversible charge capacities of 1632.1 mA h g−1 in 0.0–3.4 V and 689.1 mA h g−1 in 1.0–3.4 V.
4.4. CuxSx Micro/Nanomaterials
As the reaction of copper sulfides with lithium offers high capacity an energy density, they become attractive electrode materials in today’s energy storage. However, the reversibility is poor and nanostructuring is considered necessary to achieve moderate improvements. Next we take examples to talk about the copper sulfur compounds materials.
First of all, we talk about Cai et al.’s work. They studied by controlling the amount of Cu in the Cu-S composite nanomaterials with a novel approach.[153] They synthesize the CuxS/ Cu (1 < x < 2) nanotubes via a facile wet chemical approach in polyethylene glycol (PEG). And the changing of the reaction time can adjust the weight ratio of Cu in the CuxS/Cu materials (the sample after a 30 min reaction is S-30, after a 60 min reaction is S-60, after a 120 min reaction is S-120). They presynthesized the Cu nanowires and transformed them to nanotubes in a mass diffusion process. Then a thin PEG layer adsorbed on the nanotube surface in physically. Figure 24a–c shows the low-magnification and high-magnification FESEM images of the three complex substances. Next, they devoted the samples into the electrochemical performance tests. As shown in Figure 24d–f, it is not hard to see that during the 50th cycle,
Part. Part. Syst. Charact. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/ppsc.201600150
Figure 23. (a) SEM images of the Co3O4 hexapods. (b) SEM images of the as-prepared Co3O4-C samples. (c) Cycling performance of the Co3O4 electrodes at current densities of 100 and 500 mA g−1. (d) Cycling performance of the carbon-coated Co3O4 electrodes at current densities of 100 and 500 mA g−1. Reproduced with permission.[150] Copyright 2012, Royal Society of Chemistry.
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim20 wileyonlinelibrary.com

S-60 (with 10 wt% Cu) exhibited a better cycling stability from 468 mA h g−1 to 465 mA h g−1 while S-30 reserved discharge capacity of 371 mA h g−1 (the fifth-cycle discharge capacity of 380 mA h g−1) and S-120 reserved discharge capacity of 526 mA h g−1 (the fifth-cycle discharge capacity of 535 mA h g−1). Furthermore, when responded at different C rates, S-60 sample electrode delivers fifth-cycle discharge capacities of 330 and 282 mA h g−1 at current densities of 2 and 5 A g−1, respectively. Taken altogether, these CuxS/Cu electrodes prepared in PEG show good Li ion charge/discharge cycling stability, which is better than the CuxS/Cu sample prepared in ethanol.
Cu2S synthesized by Fu et al. is used as cathode in lithium cells with ether-based electrolytes.[154] For its excellent electrochemical performance, Cu2S shows us that in the first cycle the discharge voltage plateau can reach at 1.7 and 2.25 V and to 1.74 and 1.94 V the discharge voltage plateau slowly evolve in the following cycles respectively. We can analyze this transition process by ex situ X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). During cycling, crystalline products were deposited. Li2S and elemental copper are the discharged products and Cu1.96S is the charged product. After a capacity decline in the first cycle, the Cu2S electrodes show a metastable discharge capacity of around 250 mA h g−1 at different rates of C/10, C/5, and C/2. As the rate increases, the Coulombic efficiency sets out to decrease in early cycles. Because of the large particle size, the cyclability
and Coulombic efficiency are not as high as concerned at high rates like 1 C rate and this indicates that the transition process is limited at high rates.
Wang et al. synthesized copper sulfides in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent.[155] They heat different stoichiometries of the mixture of copper and sulfur powders. As ‘copper excess’ of copper sulfides electrodes, the electrodes show excellent electrochemical performance. These electrodes exhibit excellent electrochemical properties such as being charged and discharged at high rate and have good capacity retention. During discharge-charge process the S element in the copper excess electrode transfers into the crystal of Cu2S, which is investigated mostly as the reaction mechanism of copper sulfides. All kinds of results show that copper-excess copper sulfides with high rate capability will be a hopeful material for lithium batteries.
Another example is still about copper sulfides. Jache et al. show that the dominant factor for the reversibility of the cell reaction is the electrolyte.[156] Their reactive raw materials are just available copper sulfides (CuS and Cu2S) with no special nanostructure. Among LiPF6 in EC/DMC and LiTFSI in DOL/ DME, they tested different electrolyte compositions. Cells with ether-based electrolytes exhibit much better electrochemical performances than that contained carbonate-based electrolytes when rapid capacity fading is found. For example, after cycled more than 150 cycles in a mixture of 1 m LiTFSI in DOL/DME

Ren et al. synthesized the CuS@reduced graphene oxide (CSG) to employ as the anode material in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs).[157] Their method is to disperse CuS nanoparticles to the surfaces of reduced grapheme oxide (rGO) nanosheets. As shown in Figure 25a to c. The existence of rGO nanosheets is the reason of greater structure stability and electrical conductivity of CSG. For example in Figure 25d and e, the reversible capacity can be up to 648.1 mA h g−1 in the original cycle. Meanwhile, at the 100th cycle, the discharge capacity can maintain 710.7 mA h g−1 which is 83.5% of the first discharge capacity up to 851 mA h g−1, and 114.3% of the theoretical value of CSG. At the current density of 0.2 C, the CSG exhibits wonderful Coulombic efficiency of 99.1% and this is superior to (come near 4.5 times) the pure CuS anode of 159.7 mA h g−1 at the 100th cycle. This could thank to the synergistic effect of rGO nanosheets and CuS nanoparticles in the double-sandwich-like CSG hybrids.
Meng et al. used atomic layer deposition (ALD) to make nanoscale copper(I) sulfide (n-Cu2S) deposit over networks of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs).[158] At the time of maintaining a high porosity for efficient transport of charges, the synthesized core-shell SWCNT-n-Cu2S makes sure that between the two components, it can have intimate contacts. The morphology is shown in Figure 26. Indeed, the coreshell SWCNT-n-Cu2S demonstrates excellent electrochemical properties that it can sustain a high capacity of 260 mA h g−1 after 200 discharge-charge cycles which is 92% of the theoretical value of Cu2S and >99% Coulombic efficiency. According to above, this synthesized core-shell SWCNT-n-Cu2S may become a promising nanoscale electrode material in future application of lithium batteries.

sections.heading: 4.5. Te-Cu Composites
sections.text: Copper telluride nanocubes, nanosheets, and nanoparticles were prepared Han et al. via a solvothermal method under the protection of an inert atmosphere.[82] The influence of reaction parameters was comprehensively investigated such as precursor concentration, precursor ratio and so on. As anodes in lithium-ion batteries, the obtained copper telluride nanostructures were tested. The assembled Li/LiPF6/CuxTe cells exhibit extremely high cycling stability (up to 5000 cycles) and their highest specific capacity is 280 mA h g−1. Compare with those of electrodes made from nanoparticles and nanocubes, the Cu2-xTe nanosheet electrodes exhibit wonderful performances which demonstrate the importance of controlling the morphology of copper telluride during preparation.

sections.heading: 4.6. Si-Cu Composites
sections.text:
Restrictions in silicon based anodes have been the subject of many researches for years.[159] As an innovative approach, Polat et al. have adopted ion assisted deposition technique to produce a unique helical shaped gradient film in which the Cu/Si atomic ratio decreases from the bottom to the top of the coating. This unique film (high surface area) has more spaces to create promoting mechanical integrity and reaction between active materials (silicon) with lithium ions. To compare with the performance of the SiCu electrode, they deposited a pure Si film in the same experimental condition. Galvanostatic test results show that although the film with pure Si helices fails after 30th cycles, the compositionally graded anode exhibits a capacity of 1228 mA h g−1 at the 100th cycles with 99.5%

With a thermal roll-to-roll process followed by electroformation and LPCVD which is shown in Figure 27a, Kim et al. present an amorphous Si anode deposited on a Cu nanopillar current collector for application in high-rate Li-ion batteries. The morphology of the as-fabricated blanket film and a-Si/3DCu electrode with 250 and 500 nm diameter nanopillars are shown in Figure 27b to d. With diameters of 250 and 500 nm of Cu nanopillar current collectors, the 1 μm pitch and 2 μm height can optimize the diameters of the pillars for better electrochemical performance. Compared 250 and 500 nm diameter nanopillars, we can see the results from Figure 27e and f. Void spaces between Cu nanopillars allowed not only greater effective control of the strain caused by the Si expansion during lithiation than that allowed by a nonpatterned electrode but also significantly improved cycle performance even at 20 C measured after the same rate test: After 100 cycles at 0.5 C, the patterned electrodes with 250 and 500 nm diameter nanopillars showed high capacity retentions of 86% and 84%, respectively.[160] These electrodes retained discharge capacities of 1057 and 780 mA h g−1 even at 20 C, respectively.

sections.heading: 4.7. Ti-Cu Composites
sections.text:
TiO2 has received significant research interest as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries due to its robustness and safe operation.[161] By using a soft-template assisted method, Cao et al. organized Cu/TiO2 nanoarchitectured electrode materials with copper nanowires as their own current collectors. During the process, they controlled hydrolysis of tetrabutyl titanate in
the presence of Cu-based nanowires. Different thermal treatments were used to obtain two types of Cu/TiO2 nanocomposites with different TiO2 grain sizes.[162] Compared with bare TiO2, they exhibited much enhanced rate performances. A highrate capability is observed for the Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite with smaller TiO2 grain size. For example, at the reversible capacity of 7500 mA g−1, the capability can retain 58% of its initial capacity at 50 mA g−1. Above improvements may thanks to the integrated Cu nanowires as mechanical supports and efficient current collectors.

sections.heading: 4.8. Mn-Cu Composites
sections.text:
For manganese copper alloy, nanodimensional monodispersed Cu-MnO heterostructures were synthesized by Tan et al. through an easy solution-based method. To prevent agglomeration of organic surfactants during the growth process, Cu-MnO heterostructures with narrow size distribution has played an important role. In addition, the unique architecture of carbon-coated Cu-MnO (Cu-MnO@C) core-shell heterostructures were obtained after a thermal annealing process. Herein, at higher rate charge/discharge cycling, the eminent role of Cu was manifested shown in Figure 28a. At the high current density of 3 A g−1 (3.97 C), the 0.5Cu-MnO@C could still deliver 200 mA h g−1, much higher than the 0.1Cu-MnO@C and MnO@C counterparts which only achieve 119 and 51 mA h g−1.[163] As shown in Figure 28b, the bare MnO@C exceed the Cu-MnO@carbon heterostructures and as the rapid capacity fading it can only reach an average of 410 mA h g−1. On the contrary, after 100 cycles, the 0.1Cu-MnO@C and 0.5CuMnO@C heterostructures stabilized within the first 10 cycles and preserved about 604 and 629 mA h g−1.

sections.heading: 4.9. Ni-Cu Composites
sections.text: In the following example, Wu et al. used a modified hydrothermal synthesis and post-annealing method to make the growth of aligned, single-crystalline NiO nanoflake arrays directly on copper substrates.[50] As proof-of-concept, anodes made of this material exhibited a high capacity and excellent cycling stability. As show in Figure 29, at a current density of 100 mA g−1, the capacity can retain at 720 mA h g−1 even over 20 cycles which is much higher than the NiO products formed in the same growth solution. So much that the NiO nanoflakes grown on Cu were in the position to retain a capacity of 500 mA h g−1 over 40 cycles at a high discharge–charge rate of 1 A g−1 (1.5 C). Their experience may suggest that NiO nanoflakes possibly become a promising anode material for a high-power lithium-ion battery.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
In this review, we briefly introduce the producing method, morphology and electrochemical properties of several types of copper based materials. Those composite materials show excellent capacitance value, high rate capability and good charge/ discharge cycling stability. Understanding the elementary physical transport problems of electrons and li-ions helps to design materials with better rate performance, which becomes more and more important with the growing demands from the energy storage industry. Various synthesis approaches of nanostructured copper-based compounds are discussed with examples of their good electrical properties. Previous studies on the copper nanomaterials for lithium-ion batteries are still going on. Nerveless, existing problems of copper based materials such as electrical behaviors have more potential to progress. Herein, we give some factors which should be considered in the future research: i) increasing the amount of active material loaded may increase the activity of copper-based material, however, a trade-off between the high mass-loading should be noticed. ii) Trying to control the specific surface area of copper-based materials. It has been proved that high specific surface area can provide efficient contact with the electrolyte ions and make more electro-active sites for energy storage. iii) The combination of carbon source materials and copper-based materials will make the electrochemical performance tests signalize. Carbon source material has good electrical conductivity and the synergistic of it with copper-based materials can maximize the benefits from all components, making this approach way to improve the performance of single copper-based materials. Meanwhile, the fundamental understanding of electrode structures, the electrode/electrolyte interface, and chargestorage mechanisms is important for future studies. From the current study, along with the development of energy storage, copper-based nanomaterials will be increasingly used in future technology.

metadata.abstractText: With the increasing energy demands for electronic devices and electrical vehicles, anode materials for lithium-ion batteries with high specific capacity, good cyclic and rate performance become one of the focal areas of research. A class of them is the copper-based nanomaterials that have thermal and chemical stability, high theoretical specific capacity, low price and environment friendliness. Now this kind of nanomaterials has been recognized as one of the critical materials for lithium-ion batteries due to the predicted future market growth. Current status of different copper-based materials which produced already are discussed. In this review, comprehensive summaries and evaluations are given in synthesis strategies, tailored material properties and different electrochemical performance. Recent progress of general copper-based nanomaterials for lithium-ion batteries is carefully presented. voltage, and low self-discharge rate. Applications of lithium-ion batteries are ranging from portable consumer electronics to aerospace and electric vehicles.[27–29] As compared with other batteries, lithium-ion battery still have some disadvantages, such as insufficient energy density and power density, safety issues, depending on the quality of the electrode and electrolyte materials.[30,31] So far, many efforts have been done to improve the performances of lithium-ion battery. The energy density problem can be overcomed by developing novel electrode materials like lithium metal or silicon-(active metal) alloys which represent better hope for quite great enhancement in capacity.[32–34] Usually, the electrode material can provide pathways for shuttling lithium ions, benefitting both fast ion transport and charge balance.[35] Electrode materials are the determining factor for the battery performances. In many applications, electrode materials require not only high electrical conductivity and thermal conductivity, but also sufficiently high strength, hardness, heat resistance and wear resistance.[36–39] In previous research, carbonaceous materials have played key roles in anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Yet there still existed the unsolvable safety problem about lithium dendrite growth on the surface of carbon anodes.[40] As a result, developing new anode materials with improved cycling performance, high working potential and outstanding thermal stability to substitute conventional carbonaceous materials has become a top priority. New materials with higher energy density, better safety, and faster charge/discharge speed are critical to achieve better performances.[41,42] Nanomaterials which differs from their bulk nature have been extensively studied (such as the transition metal oxide nanostructures of Fe2O3, Co3O4, NiO and ZnO, etc.).[13,43–48] These types of materials have many advantages and great potential in terms of energy storage and conversion applications.[49–54] How to control their synthesis, surface morphology and use of their advantages in terms of energy storage and conversion becomes particularly important.[55–63] Conventional battery materials may not completely meet the requirement of the rapid development of modern society.[64,65] In metal matrix composites, there is a striking copperbased composite material. Copper is the most widely used metallic materials according to the history.[9,66] Based on charge storage mechanism, copper-based nanomaterials are well known as a typical electrode material.[67–72] With the effort of a large number of predecessors, now we can add transition J.
